segments.text: which can't because I wasn't even involved in transit planning at the time, was they looked like very different beasts in the way that they were perceived in the public and all just a matter of perception.
What the issue was in this particular referendum was there was a fat line on a map that was a heavy rail and it only served certain areas
And it was not clear to a lot of people how the other areas would be served and actually would benefit from the system, the concept being that this is our heaviest corridor.

This is where we could achieve significant savings by putting in a capital intensive facility that would result in operation savings and feed the rest of the system into this, serve the same activity centers that need to be served.
Dallas, on the other hand, came out proposing a huge system
covering their entire region, showing what they would like to see it look like at build out.
And I think did a much better job of showing the full comprehensive system.
That's not to say that Metro didn't have a full comprehensive system in mind.
There was no way we could not have had to be in line with the alternatives analysis procedures that the Urban Mass Transportation Administration requires.
You have to do an incredibly detailed level of work on your operating plan, how it will
affect your system.
So the planning had been done.
It was just, I think, presented differently.
And it looks a lot different.

To my mind, that was a lot of the voter reaction, was that we were just showing a segment serving the middle class area, when in fact, we were just showing a fixed guideway there and potentials another.
What that led to was going back to the drawing board, refining the plans some more to reflect, obviously, what the voters didn't want.
So the board worked with staff, proposed several systems.
The board eventually got down to considering alternatives A, B, and C, which were rail-intensive systems, or bus-only systems, or primarily bus systems with
where some segments of rail were justified, where we could get operational savings.
That option C was selected.
And that's what you see here on this regional transit plan map.
And it pretty much just shows you where the fixed guideways are, our proposals for fixed guideways.
You see the various corridors.
We discussed early transitways in Gulf Freeway, in the North Freeway.

along 290, the Northwest Freeway, I-10, and 59, showing other proposals we discussed before, future extensions on East X-59 North, 288 South, and just a variety of other corridors that look like fixed guideways would be needed.
This is the Fort Worth and Denver Railroad right-of-way.
That is a good direct access to the 1960 area, and use of that corridor would
would give us a good commute.
It looks like it's going out to Tumble.
Yeah, it's just to that whole 1960 area.
This would provide you several alternatives to funnel traffic into the major activities.
The stars you see here are proposed major transit centers using sort of the airline hubbing concept to feed you into a hub and then offer you alternatives to get to other areas.
For example, Northwest traffic being funneled into the Northwest Transit Center, which will be developed at the site of the intersection of the West Loop 16 and I-10 West.
We've acquired the site to build that facility and are working on designing it at this point.
The others proposed, of course, downtown is considered a major transfer center.
The South Rice Transit Center at
59, the Southwest Freeway, and the West Loop 610.
And this was originally proposed further out on the West Park system.
The concept has been revised a lot since then.
This was adopted.
The option C was adopted by the board.
The board recommended that staff go back and reevaluate some particular areas that they thought needed very close attention.
So the Regional Transit Plan is adopted after sincere study.
It was adopted in 1986, March of 86.
In its pretty much final form, you can see how there is some difference in the way the guideways are defined.
An additional regional transit center, the concept being that the routes will now have sub-regional transit centers that will serve neighborhoods.
route you into one and give you express buses to different locations.
And the fixed guideways have been looked at, refined somewhat.
One of the major revisions to the refining the regional plan was the east side improvements.
A lot of discussion of the equity issue that the east end is primarily a minority and low-moderate income area, a Hispanic neighborhood.
in the south of the Ship Channel and primarily a black and Hispanic mixed neighborhood in the northeast side of Houston.
So a great deal of analysis went in there.
A task force was created composed of Metro staff members and community representatives that worked long and hard, held public meetings, had a lot of sessions in defining it.
And the conclusion of that task force that the best way to serve the East End

remains with a very good, solid bus system that routes you into transit centers, shown here, and gets you to a system connector proposed for phase two that would get you to the major activity centers.
So this has been adopted.
This is the regional transit plan, which the authority is operating under at this point.
And as you can see, we're under construction
the outer reaches of the system on the guideways.

By the end of our first phase of the plan, which is a five-year plan in 1991, we will have completed 69 miles of transitways and freeway rights of ways on the Gulf, North, Northeast, and Katy and Southwest freeways.
And phase two of the plan, to be built out by year 2000,
is we refer to as the system connector, which is a transit corridor we've identified in a loop shape in the inner city area.

And a lot of our recent study that's summarized in this report called Building a Regional System is examination of how this phase two system will be done, what will be done in phase three, how it will tie into phase one.
So what you have is, in phase one, the development of a lot of your base facilities, the transitways,
the major transit centers, the minor transit centers in the neighborhoods, expanding the bus fleet, expanding the route system, building new bus maintenance facilities to keep up with demand.
Phase two becomes the system connector, looking at how to connect the major transit centers and the transit ways and the activity centers to implementation of that phase two
gives us a full regional system.
It gives you the ability to go in a reasonably timely fashion from one point in the metro region to another point.
And I just say reasonably because you have to consider the size of the area we're serving.
It's a huge area.
You know, almost equivalent to the, well, it's a good portion of Harris County.
So it's huge.
At some point, it's 50 miles in width.
So it's a huge system to serve.
Yeah, Ephraim was saying that the ETJ is bigger than the state of Delaware.
It's probably in excess of, what, 1,200 square miles now, probably more than that.
Our system isn't as large as the ETJ.
It isn't the same configuration as the ETJ.
I don't know how the square mileage compares.
Any of the technologies that we're looking at for the second phase, the system connector, would be interchangeable like the system you were describing.
We already operate the system of offering monthly passes
or individual fares.
And with the transfer, an individual fare allows you one transfer to an additional bus to complete your trip.
When we're looking at fixed guidelines like a light rail system at grade or a completely grade separated light rail system or an elevated bus way that's completely grade separated, which are

the three capital systems we looked at, or system connector, you would be able to move from the bus system to that without paying an additional fare, or vice versa, to move either direction and be able to transfer without a cost.
OK. Mike, has there been any serious discussion here at Metro of the perennially discussed
triangle for a rail transit between San Antonio, Houston, and Dallas.
I think there's probably been some discussion.
I don't know much about it.
I'm familiar with the system.
Does it periodically appear in the press and that sort of thing, and then one never hears anything more about it?
It was discussed again.
The marketing rep for it made a presentation at the APA conference in El Paso last fall and described the system and their proposed location for their terminal in Houston.
But there wasn't any discussion of local system interface.
Their proposed location of their station would not allow us to directly interface with our proposed alignment.
That would be a killing thing if it didn't.
And this is what BART is facing now in San Francisco.
They should have purchased the Southern Pacific right-of-way

which would enable them to go from CBD to the airport directly, rather than going all the way out to the beach practically, and then back down through very difficult terrain in Daly City to the airport, which is what they're contemplating doing.
Really?
And it would make the trip about three times as long in time as it really should be.
We don't include a direct line or a fixed guideway system to either Hobby or Intercontinental airports in our planning through phase three.
We believe basing a lot, of course basing our whole system on ridership and the kind of facilities needed to offer a viable alternative to the automobile, which
relates to how congested is a particular roadway.
Does that congestion warrant putting us out and building us in our own exclusive right of way?

With the regional mobility plan going into effect, a lot of that being implemented, the implementation of Hardy Toll Road would provide excellent access, the extension of the North Freeway bus transit way.
which we're working on now on the environmental assessment and the cost-effectiveness evaluations.
And we already have grant funding from Urban Mass Transit Administration in place to help build that facility, and we have capital set aside
to match that grant, we'll have that system extended all the way out to 1960.
And so that will provide an exclusive guideway to that facility.
With that, and potentially eventually building a facility on the Eastex freeway, we'll have a lot of alternatives to get to the airport.
And Intercontinental just could best be served using bus, even express bus, if the demand's there on Hardy Tell Road to Intercontinental.
That's the best service there.
We already serve Hobby directly, our Belford bus.
We have a couple of buses.
I think it's the Belford Crosstown drives through the Hobby garage to the drop off porch at Hobby.
So we're already providing some service.
It's not express service.
But that demand doesn't really seem to show itself.
We're having biome to requirements to address the corridors that are the most congested.
And that always brings us back to this corridor that's embodied in the system connector corridor.
where all these activity centers are in close proximity to each other.
This system connector, now the board is mulling over some various alternatives that would link it to the Texas Medical Center.
And then further down to the Astro Domain area, which is the Astro Dome, Astro World, that area.
And then with an extension eventually running over to the area
where we're building the southeast transit center to serve east side patrons.
So that would give us a good link.
Then in phase three, we would look at this Fort Worth and Denver cart going up to 1960.
When you use the term guideway, what exactly does that mean?
Okay.
The guideway itself can be any kind of guideway that's an exclusive right-of-way for a transit vehicle.
The bus transitways that exist down the North Freeway and the Katy Freeway are transit guideways.

The proposals for Phase 2 of the plan, the system connector, again, we're grade-separated rail, and it's exclusive right-of-way, either elevated or subway, and completely removed from traffic, no conflicts.

um a system a busway alternative which has an exclusive bus guideway elevated in the southern part of this along the southwest freeway and then with ramps into the downtown area and an automated guideway transit facility going through the post oak area a driverless train that we go from
Northwest Transit Center, down to the South Rise Transit Center.
That was the second alternative we've evaluated.
The third is an alternative called a light rail alternative.
It's at grade, street level light rail, such as Portland or the Muni system on the streets in San Francisco or a variety of other systems.
It's a popular technology that's proven to be real economical.
That system run in San Diego, Tijuana Trolling.
Yeah, very similar kind of technology.
It's powered by overhead wires.
We would be in our own exclusive right of way running down Main Street with a transit mall on Main Street, which is proposed for all of our alternatives.
Then it would go out, transition,

go through Midtown and go into Richmond Avenue and east-west thoroughfare, run along Richmond, transition into West Park and run to the South Rice Transit Center, then run up through the Post Oak Galleria area on Post Oak Boulevard and then along the edge of the loop, 610 west into this transit center.
That would provide for some future extensions to other areas.
as the grade-separated rail or the busway would.
The other alternatives we consider are a very close examination of the TSM, or transportation system management, which is making do with the existing street system and using relative low cost.
Even still, that alternative
includes the automated driverless train, the AGT for Post Oak, just because of the congestion factors.
We can never serve that area well with buses given the projections that we have.
And of course, the final alternative in the UMTA alternatives analysis is the no action alternative.
So staff has spent the past year working on evaluating these different alternatives

Their recommendation to the board of directors was that the street level light rail system be chosen as the alternative, given the fact that the cost of the system compared to the efficiencies it provides gives us the best system and still gives us adequate operation time.
And because the way the system can be financed compared to more expensive
Great Separated Rail or Busway.
It allows us to do these other extensions that I mentioned before earlier than we could have otherwise.
Move some extensions of the system, like to the Texas Medical Center and Southeast Transit Center, into Phase 2 instead of deferring them to Phase 3.
And the board's considering the system now, looking at some alternatives to it and refining it, maybe considering moving the Harrisburg corridor that serves East End in early, although
That's just speculation.
And that alternative appears to be the best.
They're considering that at the end of July 87.
They're supposed to give us some direction on what they think is the most valid.
And that time, we'll begin developing a draft environmental impact statement of that system, doing all the cost effectiveness evaluation that UMTA requires.
And approximately a year after that,
be in shape to say whether it's actually the best system or not.
The draft environmental impact statement will continue the evaluation of all the alternatives.
You're going to be busy.
Yeah.
It's an amazing system.
I've worked here for a year, I guess a year and a week.
And it's just been amazing, the workload that's put on.
Especially given, amazingly enough, or maybe not even surprisingly, the change in the economy made the job
much more difficult.
We had to contract with HGAC to revise the population projections.
Because those all go into our modeling, figuring out ridership, and how everything's formatted.
And that's a very difficult job to do.
Data of that magnitude, demographic data, here goes through a thing called the Interagency Database Task Force.
that reviews all the projections and representatives from all the major agencies and organizations that are users of that data.
Highway department, the city, the metro, the county, all agree and adopt that particular information.
So all that information had to be down.
Yeah, Ephraim mentioned that.
And it was interesting to hear that there is that level of cooperation, because there isn't even that level of cooperation
within the agencies of the state government in Boston.
They usually come out with two forecasts.
Really?
That review is very comfortable.
I think it's a very valid thing to do.
Sure.
It sounds like the way to go.
The most qualified people are there examining it, and I think it really gives it a lot of forethought goes into the projections.
We ended up, of course, we had a down
grade our revenue forecast because of sales tax problems.
Oh, yeah.
